Name: Benzyl 4-amino-3-chloro-6-(4-chloro-2-fluoro-3-methoxyphenyl)-5-fluoropyridine-2-carboxylate
Description: Florpyrauxifen-benzyl is a benzyl ester resulting from the formal condensation of the carboxy group of florpyrauxifen with the hydroxy group of benzyl alcohol. An auxin herbicide developed by Dow AgroSciences. It has a role as a herbicide and a synthetic auxin. It is a benzyl ester, an aromatic ether, a biaryl, a member of monochlorobenzenes, a member of monofluorobenzenes and an aminopyridine. It is functionally related to a florpyrauxifen.

plant_translocations.content: Additional active ingredients are needed for use in aquatic systems to respond to new threats or treatment scenarios, enhance selectivity, reduce use rates, and mitigate the risk of herbicide resistance. Florpyrauxifen-benzyl is a new synthetic auxindeveloped for use asanaquatic herbicide. A study was conducted at North Carolina State University in which 10 μgL−1 of 25% radiolabeled florpyrauxifen-benzyl was applied to the isolated shoot tissue of 10 different aquatic plant species to elucidate absorption and translocation patterns in these species. Extremely high levels of shoot absorption were observed for all species, and uptake was rapid. Highest shoot absorptions were observed for crested floatingheart [Nymphoides cristata (Roxb.) Kuntze] (A192 = 20 μgg−1), dioecious hydrilla [Hydrilla verticillata (L. f.) Royle] (A192 = 25.3 μgg−1), variable watermilfoil (Myriophyllum heterophyllum Michx.) (A192=40.1 μg g−1), and Eurasian watermilfoil (Myriophyllum spicatum L.) (A192=25.3 μgg−1). Evidence of translocation was observed in all rooted species tested, with the greatest translocation observed in N. cristata (1.28 μgg−1 at 192 hafter treatment). The results of this study add to the growing body of knowledge surrounding the behavior of this newly registered herbicide within aquatic plants.
plant_translocations.reference: Haug, E. J., Ahmed, K. A., Gannon, T. W., & Richardson, R. J. (2021). Absorption and translocation of florpyrauxifen-benzyl in ten aquatic plant species. Weed Science, 1–7. doi:10.1017/wsc.2021.38

method.Test Plant: 10 aquatic plant species including Eurasian watermilfoil (Myriophyllum spicatum L.), hybrid Eurasian watermilfoil (Myriophyllum spicatum L. × Myriophyllum sibiricum Kom.), variable watermilfoil (Myriophyllum heterophyllum Michx.), dioecious hydrilla, monoecious hydrilla, Brazilian egeria (Egeria densa Planch.), American eelgrass (Vallisneria americana Michx.), crested floatingheart [Nymphoides cristata (Roxb.) Kuntze], giant salvinia (Salvinia molesta Mitchell), and water hyacinth [Eichhornia crassipes (Mart.) Solms]
method.Apply Location: Each treatment vessel was equipped with a custom-built, 24-slot, stainless-steel test tube rack. To contain the 10 species slated for treatment, two tank types labeled "Tank A" and Tank B" were established, each with 4 submersed species and 1 floating species. Each tank type was replicated three times for a total of six treatment tanks. Six experimental units of five species were placed in Tank A and in Tank B for a total of 30 plants per tank. Ten different species were represented across the two tank types. Tank A species were N. cristata, dioecious H. verticillata, M. spicatum, S. molesta,andM. heterophyllum. Tank B species were E. densa,hybridM. spicatum × M. sibiricum, monoecious H. verticillata, V. americana,andE. crassipes. Plants were placed in test tube racks within holding buckets before treatment, and all plants were lowered into the treatment vessels following application of the 14C-labeled herbicide and formulation blank.
method.Plant Grown Condition: Growth chamber set for 20/15°C day/night temperatures, 12-hour photoperiod, and photosynthetic photon flux density of 250 μmol/m²/s. The aquatic plant species were grown in temperature- and light-controlled room. Glass treatment vessels containing 7 L of tap water treated with water conditioner were used.
method.Chemical Preparation: Agarose gel (1.5% v/v) (Phytagar, Invitrogen, Grand Island, NY 14075) placed on the sand surface for submersed plants. 14C-labeled florpyrauxifen-benzyl was prepared.
method.Pesticide Application Details for the Pl: 10 μg ai L−1 florpyrauxifen-benzyl applied to treatment vessels.

plant_translocations.content: Florpyrauxifen-benzyl is a new active ingredient that offers an alternative mechanism of action for weed control in rice (Oryza sativa L.). Research studies were conducted to investigate the effects of soil moisture on the absorption, translocation, and metabolism of florpyrauxifen-benzyl in three troublesome weeds. In the absorption/translocation study, barnyardgrass (Echinochloa crus-galli), hemp sesbania (Sesbania herbacea), and yellow nutsedge (Cyperus esculentus) were treated with [14C]florpyrauxifen-benzyl under two soil moisture conditions: 7.5% and 60% field capacity. The results showed that greater absorption occurred under moist soil conditions (60% soil moisture content). Additionally, more translocation of the herbicide to the area above the treated leaf was observed under moist soil conditions compared to dry soil conditions across all weed species. Sesbania herbacea exhibited the highest translocation, with 25% of the absorbed herbicide moving above the treated leaf, which was greater than the other two weed species under 60% soil moisture. However, there were no significant differences in translocation among the weed species under the 7.5% soil moisture regime. In the metabolism study, it was found that under high soil moisture conditions, S. herbacea, which is highly sensitive to even low doses of florpyrauxifen-benzyl, had 95% of the recovered herbicide in its acid form. Soil moisture also influenced the amount of acid form found in all weed species. Although these findings provide only a limited understanding of the physiological processes involved, they suggest that in the field, soil moisture content will likely play a significant role in the absorption, translocation, and metabolism of florpyrauxifen-benzyl in E. crus-galli, S. herbacea, and C. esculentus.
plant_translocations.reference: Miller, M. R., & Norsworthy, J. K. (2018). Influence of soil moisture on absorption, translocation, and metabolism of florpyrauxifen-benzyl. Weed science, 66(4), 418-423.

method.Test Plant: Weeds including E. crus-galli, S. herbacea, and C. esculentus.
method.Plant Grown Condition: A greenhouse experiment was conducted and repeated during the fall of 2016 at the University of Arkansas Altheimer Laboratory in Fayetteville, AR.Greenhouse with 32/22°C day/night temperatures.The soil included a Leaf silt loam (fine, mixed, active, thermic Typic Albaquults) containing 1.8% organic matter and with a pH of 6.1.
method.Chemical Preparation: Nonlabeled herbicide treatments of florpyrauxifen-benzyl at 30g ai ha-1.
method.Pesticide Application Details for the Pl: Four 1-μl droplets, each containing 0.416 kBq of [14C]florpyrauxifen-benzyl and MSO, were applied evenly across the adaxial leaf surface of the most mature leaf.Nonlabeled herbicide treatments of florpyrauxifen-benzyl at 30g ai ha−1 were applied POST at the 3- to 4-leaf growth stage to all weed species to simulate an early POST or pre-flood application timing in rice.
method.Other Information: The experiment was arranged as a completely randomized design with a two-factor factorial treatment structure and three replications.
